content.description:
A lightning bolt shaped, fairly clean splitter crack / dihedral which is unique for the state. 

  Starts at #2/#3's and continues to widen as it goes up.
content.location:
This route is most easily accessible by kayak/canoe.  

  Via boat: Drive on Kepler Drive north along the river, and park at the trailhead for the Cedar River Trail. 

  Row up river northwest, passing by large rock walls on the banks of the west side of the river on your left.   

  This crack should be visible from the river on one the rock faces set back further into the woods.

content.description: Basically the Incredible Hand Crack of Iowa. Short facey section followed by 25 feet of slammer hands with face holds abounding. Doesn't get much better for Iowa slimestone. "Highly recommended"Name from the petrogylph at the base of the climb, just who Melanie was and why their name adorns the climb has been lost to time. Guidebook author John Ferguson recounts a massive trundling block while photographing a friend climbing the route that eviserated two 6 inch diameter trees at the base of the climb.
content.protection: Eats pro. 0.5 for the lower section followed by 2/3s for the crack system. Anchor off tree at top or large gear.
content.location: Coonyard Wall, cross river first canyon system upriver from the dam.

content.description: Start near Melanie, workup up and right up the face using dusty and dirty two finger pockets and somewhat positive dishes to a large horizontal. This feature and pockets below are your best bet for gear. Work up to the the next horizontal on a couple side pulls vs big move up. Gas it to the top on a variety and thorough selection of holds, another horizontal along the way can afford some additional gear. Could be protected from the Melanie crack system on extension with potential for pendulum falls.
content.protection: small cams/tricams - TR anchor off tree above or large gear anchor.
content.location: Face to the right of Melanie crack system.

content.description:
The Palisades-Dows Preserve is a 162 acre preserve and home to the Eastern Iowa Observatory and Learning Center.  There are limestone rock faces along hollows and lining the Cedar River. 

  This area is located across West of the Cedar River - across the river from Palisades-Kepler State Park. 

  Be aware that there are no real hiking trails, the forest and vegetation are dense, and the hills leading to the river are steep, so this is not an easily accessible area.  Be prepared to explore / hike.
